Description.val:
DESCRIPTION: This line item funds modifications to the CH-53E - 151 and MH-53E - 28 aircraft. The aircraft inventories to be modified vary by Operational, Safety, and Improvement Program, dependant on kit modification production lead-time. The CH-53E is a seven blade main rotor and a four-blade canted tail rotor helicopter powered by three T64-GE-416/416A/419 turbo shaft engines. The CH-53E aircraft are capable of both land and ship based transport of heavy equipment, supplies, and personnel.  The MH-53E is similar to the CH-53E with additional capabilities for Airborne Mine Countermeasures, Vertical On-Board Delivery, and Special Missions which require longer range and more precise navigation than that of the CH-53E. The overall goal of the modifications budgeted in FY15 is increased communication and navigation, integrated mechanical diagnostics and condition based maintenance, propulsion and power, degraded visual environment mitigation, survivability and sustainment initiatives, and fleet operation and safety performance in the H-53 community.

Due to program priorities, funding under Integrated Mechanical Diagnostic System (IMDS 07-98) and Engine Reliability Improvement Program (ERIP  10-05) was realigned to Nacelles (09-01) and Avionics (31-12) to  accelerate Nacelle kit procurements and meet fleet driven requirements for increased communication and navigation.

 The H-53E number 1 & number 3 engine Nacelles are a safety risk due to Things Falling Off Aircraft (TFOA). To date (84) TFOA occurrences have occurred (12 in the last 3 years) on the H-53E aircraft. Of the (84) occurrences, (10) have impacted the Tail Rotor. The H-53E Engine Nacelles have become a top Direct Maintenance Man Hour driver in the fleet. This procurement would improve fleet safety and readiness. Under H-53 Avionics (31-12) additional Critical Survivability Upgrades will be installed as well as the procurement of H-53 Smart Multi-Function Color Display (SMFCD). This request will provide procurement and installation for forward deployed aircraft with integrated form, fit solution for display of Blue Force Tracker (BFT), Forward Looking Infrared with intuitive hover display, moving map and real time threat display for aircraft Survival Equipment suite in an SMFCD.  

Notes:
1.  Installs are delayed thoughout OSIPs due to aircraft availability.
2.  Critical Systems Upgrade (CSU) is comprised of BFT kits, Satellite Communicatons (SATCOM) 1851A radios, advanced digital antenna production, Heads Up Display (HUD) software, controlled display navigation unit and software upgrades in support of the Visually Degraded Environment (VDE) solution.  VDE A-kits procured in archived VDE OSIP 20-07 with FY10 OCO are occurring simultaneously with BFT/CSU installs.  Due to 4 mishaps, installation is now 151 plus the 10 trainers. Installs, QTY (58) will occur in OSIP 15-05 beginning FY13 with FY11/FY12 OCO funding.  Remaining installs QTY(103)will complete under Avionics OSIP 31-12.
3. Beginning FY15, Navy active and Navy reserve aircraft costs are separately identified in the budget exhibits.  145 active CH-53E, 6 reserve CH-53E, 21 active MH-53E and 7 reserve MH-53E aircraft comprise the H-53 fleet.  Historically, Navy active and Navy reserve funds have been budgeted to provide capability to all 179 H-53 aircraft.

CONTRACTOR INSTALLED-FIELD MOD TEAM : Installation Name: ATTEN. TRP SEATS (OSIP 020-97) CACCS

Description.val:
Utility and Troop transport mission increasing in importance.  Current troop/passenger seats are 1950 generation.  Design does not provide impact protection of current rotorcraft seat designs.  The impulsive type loading experienced during survivable mishaps produces amplified seat/floor anchor loads and potentially injurious occupant decelerations.  Due to this operational deficiency, NDI crashworthy troop seat program established.  Non-Developmental Item are lightweight off-the-shelf seats that provide protection by limiting an occupants inertial loading to survivable levels by attenuating impact forces to below survivable ranges and enables the occupant to rapidly egress a downed aircraft are being sought. 

DEVELOPMENT STATUS/MAJOR DEVELOPMENT MILESTONES:  Funding provided non-recurring engineering, qualification, initial procurement, support and installs for Crash Attenuating Crew Chief Seat (CACCS) for all H-53 Type/Model/Series helicopters. CACCS also requires a redesigned Cruise box for the MH-53E.

Notes:
1.  CACCS was incorrectly listed as B kit and has been updated to reflect A kit procurement and install schedule.  Install dollars required in FY12 and FY13.  Due to early sundown of CH-53D, QTY (22) CACCS installs will not be completed.
2.  MH-53E CATSS Kits correctly reflects prior year procurement of (5) vice (4).
3.  CATSS/CACCS installs delayed due to aircraft unavailability.
4.  (QTY) 219 CACCS procured. (QTY) 197 will be installed due to installs not completed prior to retirement of CH-53D.

Name.@footnote: Other support fluctuations are due to the CBM software upgrades.  Upgrade procurements in FY14 and FY17 require ValVer testing in the years following each upgrade.
CH-53E A-Kits QTY of 149, only 148 are actually installing.  One is not installing due to mishap.

MH-53E Kits - of the 31 procured, 2 installed kits (OCO) have been archived, leaving 29 Kits - only 28 of the 29 are installing due to mishap. Included in the remaining 28 installs is 1 trainer kit (FY13).

ImplementationMethodName.val: CONTRACTOR INSTALLED-FIELD MOD TEAM : Installation Name: IMDS (OSIP 07-98) CH-53
Not Installed - Archived A Kits OSIP 007-98

Description.val:
Integrated Mechanical Diagnostics (IMD) is a helicopter monitoring and diagnostics system that provides continuous on board monitoring and diagnostics of engine health, gearbox and drive train vibrations, oil debris, rotor track and balance. Full incorporation of the IMD system capabilities will allow rapid transition from the current costly philosophies of the 70s to today's cost wise initiatives and concepts. Lessons learned from this effort were incorporated into the solicitation for the fleet wide IMD effort with CH/MH-53E aircraft designated as the lead platforms.  IMD produces the aircraft interface required to implement military flight operations quality assurance, a capability designed to provide hazard monitoring and mitigation.  Condition Based Maintenance (CBM) is hosted within the aircraft IMDS/Health and Usage Monitoring System (HUMS), intended to direct maintenance by predicting failures based on real-time assessment of equipment condition obtained from Integrated Mechanical Diagnostics System (IMDS) embedded sensors.  CBM program includes software algorithm analysis for condition and health indicators of components,  implementation of diagnostic/analysis tools and information infrastructure.  CBM will enable a reduction in spares and maintenance while increasing safety of flight.

DEVELOPMENT STATUS/MAJOR DEVELOPMENT MILESTONES:   The CH-53E IMDS successfully completed operational evaluation in October 2005.  The Milestone Decision Authority approved full-rate production for CH-53E IMDS in December 2004. MH-53E Validation completed 1st Qtr FY11.  The MH-53E Verification was completed 1st Qtr FY13.  Advanced diagnostics enhancements and airframe structural life extension database interfaces are being incorporated to provide comprehensive platform operational and maintenance status awareness to the Squadron Commanders and key decision makers.

Notes:
1.  CH-53E A-Kits - of the 149 procured, only 148 are installing.  1 is not installing due to mishap. Not included in this count are 5 installed kits that have been archived.
2.  MH-53E Kits - of the 31 procured, 2 installed kits (OCO) have been archived, leaving 29 Kits - only 28 of the 29 are installing due to 1 mishap. Included in the remaining 28 installs is 1 trainer kit (FY13).
3.  Lack of MH-53E aircraft availability delaying installations of FY12 kit buy until FY17/18.
4.  Lack of CH-53E aircraft availability delaying installations of prior year kit buy.
5.  IMDS FY15-FY18 support costs are for IMDS configuration changes to provide continued system internet authority. CBM data will drive software changes for aging aircraft components.  
6.  Increase in Support Equipment for FY13 reflects additional test sets to improve readiness, reduce maintenance costs/time to repair the aircraft.  
7.  Prior year QTY of 1 CH-53E and 2 MH-53E installs did not occur due to loss of aircraft.
8.  CBM contract awards occur in FY14 and FY17.  FY19 support requirements will finalize software upgrades.
9.  Costs to Complete reduced due to IMDS CBM requirements fulfilled with scheduled software releases in FY17 and FY19.
10.  Non Recurring Engineering (NRE) associated with CBM is identified for each year required to support 10.0/3.0 and 11.0/4.0 software updates.

Description.val:
Material quality defects were discovered in the first production lot.  Technical data package was studied by the Original Equipment Manufacturer.  Contract awarded February 07 for Non-Recurring Engineering, tooling and validation/verification kits. 

DESCRIPTION/JUSTIFICATION:  The CH/MH-53E No.1 & No. 3 engine Nacelles are a safety risk due to Things Falling Off Aircraft (TFOA). TFOA incidents risk damage to the aircraft, threaten aircrew safety, and could potentially impact personnel and/or property on the ground.  The H-53E Engine Nacelles have become a Direct Maintenance Man Hour (MMH) driver in the fleet. The procurement improves fleet safety and readiness.  The new CH/MH-53E Nacelle ship sets incorporate improved material properties, design, and positive locking latching mechanisms to prevent TFOA.  Improved Nacelles will ensure the highest readiness levels.  

The H-53E No.1 & No. 3 engine Nacelles are a safety risk due to TFOA. To date 84 TFOA occurences have occured (12 in the last 3 years) on the H-53E aircraft.  Of the 84 occurences, 10 have impacted the Tail Rotor.  The H-53E Engine Nacelles have become a top MMH driver in the fleet. This procurement would improve fleet safety and readiness.

DEVELOPMENT STATUS/MAJOR MILESTONES:  This modification provides improvements to the engine nacelles which are intended to decrease the maintenance man-hours expended on nacelles repair and replacement.  This modification will incorporate the forward and aft engine nacelles for the H-53.

Notes:
1.  All installations are O-level.
2.  QTY of 153 CH-53E kits includes 2 trainer kits.
3.  Backbone A kits is part of the CH/MH Nacelles kit buy (associated hardware that connects the Nacelle panel to the aircraft).  Cost elements have been added due to substantial differences in kit costs - No New Start.
4.  Total qty CH Nacelles kits is 151; total qty CH backbone kits is 149 for ease of installation.

 
Current Active Modifications:
MH-53 Kit - Organic - O level install for improved GKN Nacelles to incorporate design changes to improve reliability/rigidity, risk analysis, metal numerical control (n/c) tooling, fabrication of two ship sets and teardown/inspection/test of Nacelles for No. 1 and No.3 engines.
CH-53 Kits - Organic - O level install for Improved GKN Nacelles kits.

ImplementationMethodName.val: [none specified] : Installation Name: PPC 109 Rev A

Description.val:
The T64 Engine Reliability Improvement Program (ERIP) upgrades top age related engine degraders, fatigue limiters, and performance degradation on the T64 engine. A concentrated effort is to upgrade the T64-416 engines to the T64-416A configuration by replacing components of the engine with improved hardware designs to increase reliability and reduce logistical requirements by conforming to one configuration. T64 engines will be modified to incorporate titanium nitride-coated compressor airfoils.  Titanium nitride coating provides significantly improved durability and reliability for operation in austere environments.  Degraded and obsolete peculiar support equipment will also be improved.

DEVELOPMENT STATUS/MAJOR DEVELOPMENT MILESTONES: 376 of 460 engines have been upgraded from the T64-416 to T64-416A configuration. T64-416A upgrade kits procured with FY04 Title IX Supplemental funding began installs in FY05. T64-416 and -416A engines began incorporating titanium nitride in FY04.  T64-419 engines began incorporating titanium nitride in FY06.  T64-413 engines began incorporating titanium nitride in FY07, and were completed in FY11 when the FY11 United States Marine Corps Aviation Plan was released.

Notes:
1.  All ERIP procurements are for mods catagorized as B-kits.  Contract award for FY12 quantities occurred March 2013.  
2.  Non-recurring installation cost identifies funding for T64 ERIP mods to be installed/implemented by Fleet Readiness Center (FRC) artisans.  This cost consists of labor and consumable materials necessary to implement the various Accessory Changes and Powerplant Changes that make up the T64 ERIP.  Fiscal Year quantities are based on FRC shop throughput, appropriate kit availability, and anticipated retrograde component availability.
3.  All kit procurements have completed.  Deliveries and installs will continue throughout the FYDP.  Costs for kit procurements and installs were not broken out previously.  
4.  Cost to Complete reduced due to large quantity kit orders completed; NRE, kit procurements and associated costs for Improved Wolf Gasket, Externals Improvement and Gas Generator Turbine Improvements are now funded by other programs.
5.  FY14 Congressional reduction eliminates support associated with installs; PPC 109 Rev A kit - QTY 24 installs will defer to "To Complete".  PPC 119 - QTY 51 installs added to "To Complete" QTY 60 for a total of 111.

Current Active Modifications:
1. Power Plant Changes (PPC) 109 REV A KITS - Rev A converts 416 to 416A engine configuration.
2. PPC-119 Kits procured as 419 Fuel Control Kits and Fuel Controls will be installed to upgrade T64-416A engines to the T64-419 configuration by installing modified Main Fuel Controls, Main Fuel Pumps and Fuel Flow Dividers. Total QTY 642 were procured of which 638 will install due to 4 mishaps.
3. Starting in FY 15 the schedule does not reflect Prior year information for Reserves.

ImplementationMethodName.val: CONTRACTOR FIELD MOD TEAM : Installation Name: H-53 SURVIVABILITY (OSIP 15-05) formerly Medivac (BFT
[none specified] : Installation Name: BFT/CSU Kits/VDE Solution
CONTRACTOR FIELD MOD TEAM : Installation Name: H-53 SURVIVABILITY (OSIP 15-05) formerly Medivac (CSA
CONTRACTOR FIELD MOD TEAM : Installation Name: H-53 SURVIVABILITY (OSIP 15-05) formerly Medivac (SMF

Description.val:
This funding effort is established for procurement and integration of survivability systems that will improve H-53 aircrew and passengers against hostile threats through more effective self-defense methods. The H-53 survivability strategy is to upgrade threat detection ability, increase countermeasure capability, reduce vulnerability, enhance situational awareness by communicating aircraft position to deconflict with friendly forces in the area of operation, and decrease vulnerability to battle damage by better developing protection for both the aircrew and critical components.  This increased survivability will protect the H-53 during all aspects of its various missions; assault support, shipboard delivery of cargo, anti-mine warfare, casualty transport/Medivac, and heavy cargo transport.

H-53 Smart Multi Function Color Display (SMFCD). SMFCD moving to Avionics OSIP 31-12 as of FY14.  Current Marine Air Ground Task Force (MAGTF) future force laydown plans shows Air Combat Element (ACE) MAGTF elements will not change in Operation Enduring Freedom OEF through FY14.  A MAGTF ACE will remain deployed in OEF in order to support Special Operating Forces beyond FY14 (current plans through FY16).  SMFCD improves aircrew safety by reducing pilot workload and fatigue and increases aircrew situational awareness.  SMFCD provides an integrated avionics suite that will facilitate safe landings in a degraded visual environment, modernize navigational equipment and enhance situational awareness with a joint single integrated air ground picture.  SMFCD provides the capability of displaying a Brown Out Symbology Set on the instrument panel in the pilot's normal field of view, allowing aircrews to land in dusty environments, and reducing the risk of Controlled Flight Into Terrain (CFIT) that results in loss of life and aircraft. 7 CH-53 CFIT MISHAPS FY05-FY12 (2 OIF/5 OEF) resulted in the loss of 3 aircraft and 32 people killed in action.  SMFCD provides a real time threat display for the Aircraft Survivability Equipment threat indications currently encountered, such as missiles, small arms, and lasers, overlaid on a real time moving map in the pilot's normal field of view, vice several federated systems scattered around the cockpit.  SMFCD further increases safety by eliminating the kneeboard Electronic Display Module (EDM) which currently tethers the pilot to the aircraft, creating an egress hazard during emergency situations.  Additionally, SMFCD is a form fit replacement for the current Forward Looking Infrared (FLIR) display and retains the full FLIR functionality.  All Overseas Contingency Operations (OCO) systems will be procured and installed prior to end of FY14.

DEVELOPMENT STATUS/MAJOR DEVELOPMENT MILESTONES:  Aircraft Survivability Equipment effort (18 aircraft) completed  August 2008.  Blue Force Tracker (BFT) fully equipped aircraft deployment completed June 2008.  BFT is an Army Acquisition Category IC program, encryption and L-band enhancements are anticipated.

Notes:	
1.  Critical Systems Upgrade (CSU) is comprised of BFT kits, Satellite Communicatons (SATCOM) 1851A radios, advanced digital antenna production, Heads Up Display (HUD) software, controlled display navigation unit and software upgrades in support of the Visually Degraded Environment (VDE) solution.  VDE A-kits procured in archived VDE OSIP 20-07 with FY10 OCO are occurring simultaneously with BFT/CSU installs.  Due to 4 mishaps, installation is now 151 plus the 10 trainers. Installs, QTY (58) will occur in OSIP 15-05 beginning FY13 with FY11/FY12 OCO funding.  Remaining installs QTY(103)will complete under Avionics OSIP 31-12.
2.  Lack of CH-53E aircraft availability is delaying installation of FY 12 Critical Systems Armor (CSA).
3.  SMFCD QTY (42) were procured and installed in Survivability OSIP 15-05 and have been archived.  QTY (5) SMFCD (3 production kits, 1 validation kit, 1 verification kit) were procured with FY10 supplemental (Supp)(via Above Threshold Reprogramming October 10) and are being installed in FY13/FY14 with FY11/FY12 OCO funds.QTY (25) kits were procured  based on the Omnibus 2011 II prior approval reprogramming.  QTY (37) kits were procured with FY12 OCO (OSIP 15-05) and will be installed under Avionics OSIP 31-12.  An additional QTY (94) SMFCD will be procured and installed in Avionics OSIP (31-12) for a total QTY 161 (151 aircraft installs and 10 trainers).		
4.  FY12 OCO will fund QTY (29) CSA installs.  Funds will award in 4Q FY13 and install in FY14. 
5.  Operational commitment has kept Aircraft from inducting on time, delaying installation.

Current Active Modifications:
20 BFT (OCO) kits are kept as a separate cost element.
BFT A Kits CH-53 (OCO)- NonOrganic - wiring kit for BFT.  BFT incorporates Force Battle Command Brigade and Below (FBCB2) capability in the H-53; provides near real-time tracking and displaying of friendly forces in the cockpit and increased situational awareness.  2 EDMs, and existing Global Positioning System are utilized, provides over-the-Horizon coverage with L-band Commercial SATCOM and 2-way data and Variable Message Format(VMF) messaging overlay on EDM moving map. 
CH-53E CSA A Kits (OCO)- NonOrganic - CSA program will armor critical systems including engines, gearboxes, hydraulic systems and Automatic Flight Controlled System (AFCS) to mitigate loss of critical systems and aircrew.
SMFCD A Kits - SMFCD will increase aircrew situational awareness and reduce pilot workload/fatigue by consolidating the threat warning, BFT, FLIR, hover symbology, and moving map on one easily seen "under-glass" multi-function programmable display. Integrating all this data decreases the chances for CFIT and increases situational awareness while hovering under degraded visibility conditions such as snow, sand or, dust. 
SMFCD B Kits(Validation/Verification)-OCO

Operational Commitments have kept Aircraft from inducting on time delaying installs funded with Overseas Operation Contingency (OCO) funds.

Description.val:
The H-53 Aircraft are included in the Headquarters Marine Corps Aviation Plan through Calendar Year 2025. The H-53 Aircraft Sustainment Strategy targets initiatives to remedy the top age-related maintenance degraders,  fatigue life limiters, and safety issues that impede the aircraft's ability to operate into the future. This program implements a concentrated effort to utilize improvements to the H-53 component obsolescence (e.g. Engine Air Particle Separator (EAPS) redesign), structural limitations (e.g. transition bulkhead and station 820 structural improvement), aircrew safety systems and program sustainment support. This effort will sustain the H-53 legacy fleet in an affordable manner until the H-53 follow-on aircraft becomes available.

DEVELOPMENT STATUS/MAJOR DEVELOPMENT MILESTONES:    The H-53 Sustainment Program Acquisition Strategy was approved by Program Executive Office(Aircraft) in March 2006, to be executed as five Abbreviated Acquisition Programs (AAPs) for (1) Fatigue, (2) Obsolescence, (3) Readiness, 4) Safety, and 5) Automatic Flight Control System (AFCS).  Each AAP consists of several independent projects, each of which has an independent platform effectivity, acquisition strategy, production lead time, production rate and quantity, and installation approach.  Thus, they are not amenable to a "block upgrade" type approach.  Each year of the program will involve non-recurring engineering (NRE) on some projects, leading to production and installation in out-years.  Other projects require little or no NRE and can be acquired and installed quickly during maintenance.  As of 9 December 2013, the first four AAP's were retired.

Notes:
1.   Kapton kits are comprised of various harnesses.  Kapton harnesses has been added to replace those missing/broken/damaged in order to complete required Kapton kits.
2.   Arc Fault Circuit Breakers was archived at OSD15; Arc Fault Circuit Breakers (REV 1) - QTY 179 is added to install replacement circuit breakers from manufacturer at no cost to the government for the Kit; Installs begin in FY15. 
3.  12 HEELS A1 and A3 kits were shipped to Iraq.  The entire shipment was lost in theater.  These additional kits are required to complete installs with Rev A.  There are being installed simultaneously with the Rev A Kit.

Current Active Modifications:
Aircrew Cooling-NonOrganic - installation of mini cooling units in the H-53E cabin to mitigate heat stress for aircrew.
H-53 Helicopter Emergency Egress Lighting System (HEELS) - installation of a self-contained, fiber formed electro-luminescent technology that lights escape paths for crew/passengers to maintain orientation in the event of a mishap.
Arc Fault Circuit Breaker (REV 1) (AFCB REV 1)-NonOrganic - to replace legacy circuit breakers with modernized solid-state electronic circuit breakers able to react in a timely manner to a wiring fault, reducing potential of electrical arcing and inflight fires.
Kapton Replacement Wiring Kits - Replaces deficient legacy wiring throughout the H-53E cabin. Now known to rapidly degrade with age, particularly in the maritime environment that naval aircraft operate and have been cited as the causal factor of over 100 documented incidences of electric malfunction and fire.
Obsolescent Components - installation of upgrades/replacements to various obsolete legacy components.
Safety/Readiness Improvement Kits-Organic - #2 Engine Fire Safety kits required to identify/prevent the main cause of fire during compressor stall at all power settings during flight, eliminating the #1 safety concern in the H-53 fleet; Rotor Brake Fire Prevention Kits.
Engine Start Valve Kits-Organic


Future Modifications:
Improved Transformer-Rectifier Unit-Organic
Soundproofing Retention Kits-Organic

Name.val: 1.1.8) CH-53E (Rev-A) A Kits OCO - Reserve - NonOrganic

ImplementationMethodName.val: CONTRACTOR FIELD MOD TEAM : Installation Name: DIRCM (OSIP 010-08)
Not Installed - Archived A Kits OSIP 10-08

Description.val:
Currently, the H-53 has only Infrared (IR) detection equipment and rudimentary flares for use as countermeasure.  This funding is for Engineering Change Proposal (ECP) development, A-kit procurement and installation of a Direct Infrared Counter Measure (DIRCM) system for H-53s.  This system will help protect the H-53 which is highly susceptible to IR seeking manpads, the weapon of choice in all current theaters.  This system has been found effective against fourth generation IR manpads, and is extremely effective earlier generation manpads. 

DEVELOPMENT STATUS/MAJOR DEVELOPMENT MILESTONES:  Non-Recurring engineering (NRE) for the CH-53E began in May 07 and concluded with a completed and verified Technical Directive in early FY09.  Test and Evaluation for the CH-53E began with risk-reduction testing in April 08 and concluded with Inital Operational Test and Evaluation (IOT&E)in late FY09.  Critical to early fielding was the Quick reaction assessment, completed in August 08 which lead to an Early Operational Capability (EOC) decision in November 08. Validation and verification were conducted for the CH-53E between May - September 08.  Non-Recurring engineering for the CH-53D began in May 08 and concluded with a completed and verified TD in early FY10.  The FY11 United States Marine Corps Aviation Plan was released in October 2010 and called for the early retirement of the CH-53D.  Development and deployment of the DIRCM system on the CH-53D system was subsequently suspended and remaining funding realigned to other priorities consistent with Headquarters Marine Corps direction.  DIRCM is being procured as a mission kit by PMA-272.  CH-53Es must be modified with an A-kit to accept the mission kit.  Installations surged in FY09 to achieve an EOC and then continue through FY16.  



Notes:
1.  Total QTY (161) reflects 151 CH-53E DIRCM baseline kits, (2) maintenance trainers and (8) operational trainers.
2.  FY11 CH-53 (DIRCM Rev-A) A kits QTY (153) are a revision to an existing kit.

ImplementationMethodName.val: CONTRACTOR FIELD MOD TEAM : Installation Name: H-53 AVIONICS (OSIP 031-12) - SMFCD
Contractor Field Mod Team : Installation Name: SATCOM
CONTRACTOR FIELD MOD TEAM : Installation Name: H-53 AVIONICS (OSIP 031-12) - CSU

Description.val:
This Operational, Safety and Improvement Program (OSIP) will fund avionics systems for the H-53 helicopter. The H-53 strategy is to address safety, survivability, system obsolescence, and avionics deficiencies that require correction to maintain platform relevance on an increasingly networked battlefield.  Specifically, this OSIP addresses Critical Survivability Upgrade (CSU) installations. CSU leverages the aircraft state, rate, and acceleration data available through integration of the H764G Embedded Global Positioning System/Inertial Navigation System and development of improved hover symbology in providing the Phase I Degraded Visual Environment (VDE) solution. The CSU program also provides the platform for the installation of the APX-123 Transponder meeting Mode 5 Inital Operational Capability requirements.  Targeted improvements include, but are not limited to Aircraft Survival Equipment (ASE) upgrades (including APR-39 and AAR-47), lack of 8.33 kHz frequency separation Fleet Requirements Document compliance, Area Navigation (RNAV) and Required Navigation Performance (RNP) (RNP/RNAV) certification, Variable Message Format Revision D change 1 compliance, embedded Terrain Avoidance and Warning System (eTAWS) integration, Collision Avoidance System integration, Over-the-Horizon communications and Crash Survivable Flight Data Recorder. Safety related improvements include lack of a solution mitigating Controlled Flight Into Terrain risk when operating in DVE.  Blue Force Tracker (BFT) kneeboard hazard is corrected with the incorporation of an integrated Multi-Function Display (MFD) capable of processing and displaying a variety of flight and situational awareness information to pilots. Additionally, this funding provides for the integration of cockpit avionics with ASE to provide time critical data to other battlefield users in order to more rapidly prosecute threats.  This request also funds non recurring engineering (NRE) purchase and installation of ARC-210 Satellite Communications (SATCOM) that meets over the horizon communication requirements.  Smart Multi Function Color Display (SMFCD), CSU, Blue Force Tracker (BFT), and SATCOM have transitioned from various OSIPs into Avionics. This funding effort seeks to eliminate these, and other, avionics and ASE related system level deficiencies and safety hazards with the above described improvements as well as ensuring that all H-53 aircraft are equipped with a full complement of ASE required to operate on the modern networked battlefield.

SMFCD improves aircrew safety by reducing pilot workload and fatigue and increases aircrew situational awareness.  SMFCD provides an integrated avionics suite that will facilitate safe landings in a degraded visual environment, modernize navigational equipment and enhance situational awareness with a joint single integrated air ground picture.  SMFCD provides the capability of displaying a Brown Out Symbology Set (BOSS)on the instrument panel in the pilot's normal field of fiew, allowing aircrews to land in dusty environments, and reducing the risk of Controlled Flight Into Terrain (CFIT) that results in loss of life and aircraft.  7 CH-53 CFIT MISHAPS FY-5-FY12 (2 OIF/5 OEF)resulted in the loss of 3 aircraft and 32 people killed in action.  SMFCD provides a real time threat display for the Aircraft Survivability Equipment threat indications currently encountered, such as missiles, small arms, and lasers, overlaid on a real time moving map in the pilot's normal field of view, vice several federated systems scattered around the cockpit.  SMFCD further increases safety by elimnating the kneeboard Electronic Display Module (EDM) which currently tethers the pilot to the aircraft, creating an egress hazard during emergency situations.  Additionally, SMFCD is a form fit replacement for the current Forward Looking Infrared (FLIR) display and retains the full FLIR functionality.  

H-53 SMFCD moving to Avionics OSIP 31-12 as of FY14.  Current Marine Air Ground Task Force (MAGTF) future force laydown plans shows Air Combat Element (ACE) MAGTF elements will not change in Operation Enduring Freedom (OEF) through FY14.  A MAGTF ACE will remain deployed in OEF in order to support Special Operating Forces beyond FY14 (current plans through FY16).  Current MAGTF future force laydown plans shows ACE MAGTF elements will not change in OEF through FY14. 

DEVELOPMENT STATUS/MAJOR DEVELOPMENT MILESTONES: NRE efforts for modification of eTAWS algorithm for the H-53 aircraft will be completed June 13. Production and installation effort of eTAWS capable MFD will complete in September 15.

1.  CSU is comprised of Blue Force Tracker (BFT) kits, Satellite Communicatons (SATCOM) 1851A radios, advanced digital antenna production, Heads Up Display (HUD) software, controlled display navigation unit and software upgrades in support of the VDE solution.  Due to VDE solution being comprised of the above, installation of QTY 151 (due to 4 mishaps) plus 10 trainers, VDE A-kits procured in archived VDE OSIP 20-07 with FY10 OCO are occurring simultaneously with BFT/CSU installs.  Of the (161) installs, QTY (58) are being installed in OSIP 15-05 beginning FY13 with FY11/FY12 OCO funding.  Remaining installs QTY (97)will complete under Avionics OSIP 31-12.  Remaining QTY(6) kits will procure in FY16 under Avionics OSIP 31-12.  CSU total kit QTY (161).  
2.  SMFCD total kit QTY is 161.  QTY (151) aircraft installs and (10) trainers.  QTY (67) kits were procured under OSIP 15-05 in prior years of which 5 installed.  Remaining QTY (62) installs occur under Avionics OSIP 31-12.  QTY (94) will procure/install in Avionics OSIP 31-12.  Trainers are not installed.
